title: Why fascism is so tempting— and how your data could power it - Yuval Noah Harari

multiple-choice.question: According to Yuval Noah Harari, what is the main difference between nationalism and fascism?

options.label: A
options.text: Nationalism emphasizes the importance of group identity, while fascism emphasizes the importance of individual identity.

options.label: B
options.text: Fascism denies all identities except the national identity and insists that individuals have obligations only towards their nation.

options.label: C
options.text: Nationalism is a peaceful ideology, while fascism is a violent ideology.

options.label: D
options.text: Fascism is a global ideology that promotes world peace.

multiple-choice.question: According to Yuval Noah Harari, what was the main advantage of authoritarian regimes in the 20th century?

options.label: A
options.text: Their ability to control the flow of data.

options.label: B
options.text: Their ability to manipulate people's emotions.

options.label: C
options.text: Their ability to process information efficiently.

options.label: D
options.text: Their ability to make decisions efficiently.

multiple-choice.question: According to Yuval Noah Harari, what is the main threat to liberal democracy in the 21st century?

options.label: B
options.text: The merger of information technology with biotechnology.

options.label: C
options.text: The concentration of data in the hands of a few individuals or organizations.

multiple-choice.question: According to Yuval Noah Harari, what is the main danger of fascism?

options.label: A
options.text: Fascism is a violent ideology that promotes hatred and violence.

options.label: B
options.text: Fascism is a seductive ideology that exploits people's vanity and emotions.

options.label: C
options.text: Fascism is a global ideology that promotes world peace.

options.label: D
options.text: Fascism is a local ideology that promotes regional development.

multiple-choice.question: According to Yuval Noah Harari, what is the main responsibility of individuals in the face of the dangers of fascism and authoritarianism?

options.label: A
options.text: To ignore the dangers of fascism and authoritarianism.

options.label: B
options.text: To get to know their weaknesses and avoid being manipulated by those who control the data.

options.label: C
options.text: To support the government or corporations that control the data.

options.label: D
options.text: To rise up against the government or corporations that control the data.

multiple-choice.question: According to Yuval Noah Harari, what is the main difference between corporations and governments?

options.label: A
options.text: Corporations are more powerful than governments.

options.label: B
options.text: Corporations are less powerful than governments.

options.label: C
options.text: The main difference is not significant, as both corporations and governments can control the data.

options.label: D
options.text: Corporations are more transparent than governments.

multiple-choice.question: According to Chris Anderson, what is the main concern that some people have about the control of data by big corporations?

options.label: A
options.text: That corporations will use the data to promote world peace.

options.label: B
options.text: That corporations will use the data to manipulate people's emotions.

options.label: C
options.text: That corporations will use the data to promote regional development.

options.label: D
options.text: That corporations will use the data to create a new form of government.

multiple-choice.question: According to Yuval Noah Harari, what is the main impact of the rise of artificial intelligence and machine learning on the control of data?

options.label: A
options.text: It will make it more difficult for corporations and governments to control the data.

options.label: B
options.text: It will make it easier for corporations and governments to control the data.

options.label: C
options.text: It will make centralized data processing more efficient than distributed data processing.

options.label: D
options.text: It will have no impact on the control of data.

multiple-choice.question: According to Yuval Noah Harari, what is the main reason why people are more likely to take risks and try new technologies in times of crisis?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are more optimistic about the future.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are more pessimistic about the future.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are more willing to take risks in times of crisis.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are more likely to follow the crowd.

multiple-choice.question: According to Yuval Noah Harari, what is his prediction for the future of humanity?

options.label: A
options.text: That humanity will become gods through the development of artificial intelligence or genetic engineering.

options.label: B
options.text: That humanity will become extinct due to the dangers of fascism and authoritarianism.

options.label: C
options.text: That humanity will become more peaceful and democratic.

options.label: D
options.text: That humanity will scrape through the current crisis and emerge stronger.

title: A brief history of plastic

multiple-choice.question: What was the original material used to make billiard balls before the invention of celluloid?
Why did inventors begin to look for alternatives to making billiard balls from elephant tusks?

options.label: B
options.text: Because elephant tusks were becoming too expensive

options.label: C
options.text: Because billiard ball makers were looking for a new challenge

options.label: D
options.text: Because excessive hunting caused elephant populations to decline

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with creating the first plastic in 1863?
What is the unifying feature of plastics?

options.label: B
options.text: They are always made from wood

options.label: D
options.text: They start out soft and malleable

multiple-choice.question: What was the main problem with the first plastic, celluloid?

options.label: A
options.text: It was too expensive to produce

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the hardy new polymer that was invented in 1907?
What were the advantages of Bakelite over celluloid?

options.label: A
options.text: It was cheaper to produce and made from more readily available raw materials

options.label: B
options.text: It was more flammable and made from less readily available raw materials

options.label: C
options.text: It was less flammable and made from less readily available raw materials

options.label: D
options.text: It was more brittle and made from more readily available raw materials

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the spongy plastic that was first commercially developed in the 1920s?
What were the consequences of the plastics century?

options.label: A
options.text: It was too short and created too much convenience

options.label: C
options.text: It was too expensive and created too much waste

options.label: D
options.text: It was too convenient and created too much environmental benefit

multiple-choice.question: What are some of the innovations that scientists are working on to address the problems of the plastics century?

options.label: A
options.text: Developing new types of plastics that are more flammable and expensive

options.label: B
options.text: Increasing the production of plastics and making them more expensive

options.label: C
options.text: Making plastics more expensive and harder to recycle

options.label: D
options.text: Reducing plastic use, developing biodegradable plastics, and finding new ways to recycle existing plastic

title: How to fix a broken heart - Guy Winch

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why people often struggle to recover from heartbreak, according to the author?

options.label: A
options.text: They lack the emotional resources to cope with the pain.

options.label: B
options.text: Their mind tricks them into initiating a wild goose chase for explanations.

options.label: C
options.text: They are unable to accept the reality of the situation.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not willing to let go of the relationship.

options.label: C
options.text: Because their mind is trying to balance out the negative thoughts by focusing on the positive aspects of the relationship.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are trying to move on.

title: The fish that walk on land - Noah R. Bressman

multiple-choice.question: What is a unique adaptation of the walking catfish that allows it to survive on land?

options.label: B
options.text: Its powerful fins for movement on land

options.label: C
options.text: Its ability to breathe through its stomach lining

options.label: D
options.text: Its ability to dance its way out of the water

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following fish species is an example of a fish that will only move on land when forced?
Why do fish make the exodus from water to land?

options.label: C
options.text: To escape competitive, polluted, or unhealthy environments

multiple-choice.question: What is a unique way that the armored catfish breathes on land?

options.label: A
options.text: It uses its gills to absorb oxygen from the air

options.label: B
options.text: It uses its stomach lining to absorb oxygen from the air

options.label: C
options.text: It uses its mouth to inhale oxygen from the air

options.label: D
options.text: It uses its fins to absorb oxygen from the air

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is a way that the mudskipper copes with dehydration on land?

options.label: A
options.text: It buries itself in the earth and coats its body in a mucus cocoon

options.label: B
options.text: It rolls in the mud like a puppy

options.label: C
options.text: It uses its powerful fins to move on land

options.label: D
options.text: It uses its clever tools to navigate on land

multiple-choice.question: Why does the Nopoli rock-climbing goby use its suction cups to climb waterfalls?
How does the mummichog find water while on land?

options.label: A
options.text: By using its inner ear to determine its orientation on a slope

options.label: B
options.text: By using its reflective surfaces to find water

options.label: C
options.text: By using its taste buds to sense compounds that signal the proximity and quality of nearby water

options.label: D
options.text: By using its powerful fins to move on land

multiple-choice.question: What is a unique adaptation of the lungfish that allows it to breathe on land?

options.label: C
options.text: It has a specialized gill system

options.label: D
options.text: It has a highly efficient oxygen-absorbing system

multiple-choice.question: Why does the walking catfish use its taste buds to navigate on land?

options.label: C
options.text: To find water and navigate towards water and prey

multiple-choice.question: What is a benefit of being a "fish out of water" for amphibious fishes?

options.label: A
options.text: They have access to new prey

options.label: B
options.text: They have a plan B if they need to escape competitive, polluted, or unhealthy environments

options.label: C
options.text: They can adapt to changing temperatures

title: How to outsmart the Prisoner’s Dilemma - Lucas Husted

multiple-choice.question: What is the scenario presented in the transcript called in game theory?
What happens if both gingerbread men choose to spare each other in the Prisoner's Dilemma?

options.label: A
options.text: The fox eats both of their limbs

options.label: B
options.text: The fox eats just one of each of their limbs

options.label: C
options.text: The gingerbread men run away scot-free

options.label: D
options.text: The gingerbread men are fully eaten

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the strategy that the gingerbread men use to unconditionally sacrifice their companion?
What is the Infinite Prisoner's Dilemma?

options.label: A
options.text: A scenario where the gingerbread men have to make decisions for the rest of their lives

options.label: B
options.text: A scenario where the gingerbread men have to make decisions for the rest of their lives, starting with all four limbs at each sunrise

options.label: C
options.text: A scenario where the gingerbread men have to make decisions for the rest of their lives, starting with all four limbs at each sunset

options.label: D
options.text: A scenario where the gingerbread men have to make decisions for the rest of their lives, starting with just one limb at each sunrise

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the Infinite Prisoner's Dilemma?

options.label: A
options.text: To show that the gingerbread men will always choose to sacrifice each other

options.label: B
options.text: To show that the gingerbread men can use their future decisions as bargaining chips for the present ones

options.label: C
options.text: To show that the gingerbread men will always choose to spare each other

options.label: D
options.text: To show that the gingerbread men will always choose to run away scot-free

multiple-choice.question: What is delta in the context of the Infinite Prisoner's Dilemma?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of limbs the gingerbread men care about in the present

options.label: B
options.text: The number of limbs the gingerbread men care about in the future

options.label: C
options.text: The discount rate of how much the gingerbread men care about their future limbs

options.label: D
options.text: The number of days the gingerbread men have to make decisions

multiple-choice.question: What is the optimal value of delta for the gingerbread men to spare each other?
What is the implication of the Infinite Prisoner's Dilemma in real-life situations?

options.label: A
options.text: That selfishness always wins out in the short-term

options.label: B
options.text: That peaceful cooperation is not possible

options.label: C
options.text: That rational leaders must assume that the decisions they make today will impact those of their adversaries tomorrow

options.label: D
options.text: That the decisions made today will not impact those of adversaries tomorrow

multiple-choice.question: What is the outcome of the Infinite Prisoner's Dilemma if the gingerbread men care about their future limbs at all?

options.label: A
options.text: They will always choose to sacrifice each other

options.label: B
options.text: They will always choose to spare each other

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Infinite Prisoner's Dilemma in the context of the gingerbread men's friendship?

options.label: A
options.text: It shows that their friendship will never last

options.label: B
options.text: It shows that their friendship will always be half-baked

options.label: C
options.text: It shows that their friendship will never be half-baked

options.label: D
options.text: It shows that their friendship will always be crumby

title: Evolution’s great mystery: Language - Michael Corballis

multiple-choice.question: What is a key difference between human language and animal communication?

options.label: A
options.text: Human language is more complex and nuanced.

options.label: B
options.text: Human language is limited to a specific number of messages.

options.label: C
options.text: Human language is fundamentally open-ended and can be used to say an unlimited number of things.

options.label: D
options.text: Human language is only used for storytelling.

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of great ape communication in the wild?

options.label: A
options.text: They vocalize more freely than they gesture.

options.label: B
options.text: They gesture to each other in the wild much more freely than they vocalize.

options.label: D
options.text: They do not communicate at all.

multiple-choice.question: What may have been the first stage in the development of human language?
What is a potential clue to the origins of language, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The emergence of the genus Homo

options.label: B
options.text: The split of the human lineage from other great apes

options.label: D
options.text: The use of tools by early humans

multiple-choice.question: What is a key feature of human language that allows us to say an unlimited number of things?

options.label: C
options.text: Our ability to combine simple messages into more complex ideas

options.label: D
options.text: Our ability to use abstract symbols

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of the vocal tracts of Neanderthals and Denisovans?

options.label: A
options.text: They were optimal for articulate speech

options.label: B
options.text: They were not optimal, but they likely had some vocal capacity and possibly even language

options.label: C
options.text: They were similar to those of modern humans

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential consequence of the emergence of speech in humans?

options.label: D
options.text: The decline of tool use and transport

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is a key factor that allows humans to learn any language?
What is a key question that remains unanswered in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: What is the origin of language?

options.label: B
options.text: What is the relationship between language and complex thought?

options.label: C
options.text: What came first, language or the ability to share scenarios?

options.label: D
options.text: What is the role of language in shaping humanity?

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is a potential time frame for the emergence of language in humans?

title: How to change your behavior for the better - Dan Ariely

multiple-choice.question: Why does the speaker have a half-beard?

options.label: A
options.text: He has a medical condition that affects hair growth.

options.label: B
options.text: He was badly burned in an accident.

options.label: D
options.text: He is trying to make a fashion statement.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main topic of the speaker's discussion?

options.label: A
options.text: The relationship between environment and behavior change.

options.label: B
options.text: The impact of social science on human behavior.

options.label: D
options.text: The benefits of exercise and a healthy lifestyle.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of a meta-analysis on financial literacy?

options.label: A
options.text: People who learned financial literacy showed a significant improvement in their behavior.

options.label: B
options.text: People who learned financial literacy showed a slight improvement in their behavior.

options.label: C
options.text: People who learned financial literacy showed no improvement in their behavior.

options.label: D
options.text: People who learned financial literacy showed a decrease in their behavior.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the key to changing behavior?

options.label: B
options.text: Changing the environment to make desired behavior easier.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of "friction" in the context of behavior change?

options.label: A
options.text: The small things that matter in behavior change.

options.label: B
options.text: The obstacles that prevent people from taking action.

options.label: D
options.text: The difficulty in achieving a goal.

multiple-choice.question: In the context of the online pharmacy study, what was the problem with the initial design?

options.label: A
options.text: The offer to switch to generics was too expensive.

options.label: B
options.text: The people had the no-action benefit with branded medication.

options.label: C
options.text: The offer to switch to generics was not attractive enough.

options.label: D
options.text: The people had to return a letter to switch to generics.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the study on motivating people to save money in a slum in Kenya?

options.label: A
options.text: The text message reminder was the most effective method.

options.label: B
options.text: The text message from the kids was the most effective method.

options.label: C
options.text: The coin was the most effective method.

options.label: D
options.text: The financial incentives were the most effective method.

multiple-choice.question: Why was the coin effective in motivating people to save money?

options.label: B
options.text: It made the lack of savings visible.

options.label: D
options.text: It provided a text message reminder.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the importance of making invisible economic activities visible?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps people to see the impact of their actions.

options.label: B
options.text: It helps people to make their goals more visible.

options.label: C
options.text: It helps people to save money.

options.label: D
options.text: It helps people to make better financial decisions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's final message?

options.label: A
options.text: We can close the gap between where we could be and where we are.

options.label: B
options.text: We can get much better, but it will take time and effort.

options.label: C
options.text: We should just provide people with more information.

options.label: D
options.text: We should just change the laws and regulations.

title: Grief and love in the animal kingdom - Barbara J. King

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the orca that gave birth to a daughter in July 2018, but the calf died shortly after birth?

What is the name of the two ducks that were raised at a foie gras factory and later rescued by a farm sanctuary?
According to the speaker, what is the impact of recognizing animal grief on human behavior?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes humans more likely to confine animals to small tanks.

options.label: B
options.text: It makes humans more likely to engage in international trophy hunting.

options.label: C
options.text: It makes humans more likely to reduce animal suffering by choosing plant-based meals.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no impact on human behavior.
